title: Wicked Salmon
description: Decreasing of salmon population in wild habitat are cause by over fishing and developed on the river stream such as a dam. Because salmons are Anadromous they are swiming against the river flow from the ocean and back to the freshwater for spawning.
contents:
Contents
1. Intro
1.1 Greetings
1.2 Brief
1.3 Problem Background
1.4 Library
1.5 Dataset

2. Data Preparation
2.1 Subset Columns & Rows
2.2 Check the Data
2.3 Convert Data

3 Data Exploratory and Explanatory
3.1 Most popular species

3.3 Aquaculture
3.4 Country and cultivation

4. Conclusion
5. Reference

1. Intro
1.1 Greetings
Helo, Welcome to My Rmd In this Rmd I would explore a little bit about salmon.
1.2 Brief
Data source is from FAO. There are a lot of species, however Im only need a commercial salmon species. I wont to know about the source, which country? and what the metodologi used to harvest salmon?
1.3 Problem Background
Decreasing of salmon population in wild habitat are cause by over fishing and developed on the river stream such as a dam. Because salmons are Anadromous they are swiming against the river flow from the ocean and back to the freshwater for spawning.
1.4 Library


library(readr)
library(readxl)



1.5 Dataset


fish <- read_csv("input_fish/TS_FI_PRODUCTION.csv")
species <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_SPECIES_GROUPS.csv")
country <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_COUNTRY_GROUPS.csv")
source <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_PRODUCTION_SOURCE.csv")
note <- read_xlsx("input_fish/DSD_FI_PRODUCTION.xlsx")



2. Data Preparation
2.1 Subset Columns & Rows
I only chose 7 species of salmon and for column I chose Country, Source, Species, Year, and Quantity


salmon <- fish[ fish$SPECIES %in% c("SAL", "CHI", "CHU", "COH", "CHE", "PIN", "SOC") , 
                                  c("COUNTRY", "SOURCE", "SPECIES", "YEAR", "QUANTITY")]



and then assign to the salmon data frame
2.2 Check the Data
2.2.1 Check structure data


str(salmon)


tibble [6,724 × 5] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ COUNTRY : chr [1:6724] "643" "643" "643" "643" ...
 $ SOURCE  : num [1:6724] 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 ...
 $ SPECIES : chr [1:6724] "SAL" "CHE" "CHE" "CHE" ...
 $ YEAR    : num [1:6724] 1988 1995 1994 1993 1992 ...
 $ QUANTITY: num [1:6724] 89 4 4 0 0 0 0 0 0 381 ...

2.2.2 Cek Missing data


colSums(is.na(salmon))


 COUNTRY   SOURCE  SPECIES     YEAR QUANTITY 
       0        0        0        0        0 

There is no missing data in salmon data frame
2.3 Convert Data
2.3.1 Convert country code to country name
Check country code


unique(salmon$COUNTRY)


 [1] "643" "410" "666" "840" "724" "810" "752" "124" "152" "208" "233"
[12] "234" "250" "246" "276" "304" "352" "372" "833" "392" "428" "440"
[23] "528" "554" "578" "616" "620" "826" "300" "408" "196" "036" "792"
[34] "376" "100"

Interpret county code


negara <- country [ country$UN_Code %in% c("643", "410", "666", "840", "724", 
                                           "810", "752", "124", "152", "208", 
                                           "233", "234", "250", "246", "276", 
                                           "304", "352", "372", "833", "392", 
                                           "428", "440", "528", "554", "578", 
                                           "616", "620", "826", "300", "408", 
                                           "196",  "36", "792", "376", "100") , ]
negara$Name_En


 [1] "Bulgaria"                 "Canada"                  
 [3] "Chile"                    "Cyprus"                  
 [5] "Denmark"                  "Estonia"                 
 [7] "Faroe Islands"            "Finland"                 
 [9] "France"                   "Germany"                 
[11] "Greece"                   "Greenland"               
[13] "Iceland"                  "Ireland"                 
[15] "Israel"                   "Japan"                   
[17] "Korea, Dem. People's Rep" "Korea, Republic of"      
[19] "Latvia"                   "Lithuania"

There are 34 countries in salmon data frame, however according to the FAO there are only 14 countries that contribute to the global salmon trade, So I just convert 14 countries to the salmon data frame.


salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="578"]<-"Norway"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="152"]<-"Chile"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="752"]<-"Sweden"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="208"]<-"Denmark"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="616"]<-"Poland"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="826"]<-"United Kingdom"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="840"]<-"United States of America"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="124"]<-"Canada"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="250"]<-"France"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="276"]<-"Germany"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="528"]<-"Netherlands"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="392"]<-"Japan"
salmon$COUNTRY[salmon$COUNTRY=="724"]<-"Spain"

unique(salmon$COUNTRY)

Subset 14 countires


salmon <- salmon[ salmon$COUNTRY %in% c("Norway", "Chile", "Sweden", "Denmark", "Poland", 
                                        "United Kingdom", "United States of America", "Canada", 
                                        "France", "Germany", "Netherlands", "Japan", "Spain", 
                                        "Russian Federation") , ]

unique(salmon$COUNTRY)


 [1] "Russian Federation"       "United States of America"
 [3] "Spain"                    "Sweden"                  
 [5] "Canada"                   "Chile"                   
 [7] "Denmark"                  "France"                  
 [9] "Germany"                  "Japan"                   
[11] "Netherlands"              "Norway"                  
[13] "Poland"                   "United Kingdom"          

2.3.2 Convert code of source to source name
Interpret code of source


source


# A tibble: 5 × 5
  Identifier Code          Name_En        Name_Fr        Name_Es      
       <dbl> <chr>         <chr>          <chr>          <chr>        
1          5 AQUACULTURE   Aquaculture p… Production de… Producción d…
2          1 FRESHWATER    Aquaculture p… Production de… Producción d…
3          2 BRACKISHWATER Aquaculture p… Production de… Producción d…
4          3 MARINE        Aquaculture p… Production de… Producción d…
5          4 CAPTURE       Capture produ… Captures       Capturas     

Check code of source on salmon data frame


unique(salmon$SOURCE)


[1] 4 1 3

There are only 3 of 5 source in the salmon data frame So now convert the code to the name


salmon$SOURCE[salmon$SOURCE=="1"]<-"Freshwater Aquaculture"
salmon$SOURCE[salmon$SOURCE=="3"]<-"Marine Aquaculture"
salmon$SOURCE[salmon$SOURCE=="4"]<-"Capture Fishery"

unique(salmon$SOURCE)


[1] "Capture Fishery"        "Freshwater Aquaculture"
[3] "Marine Aquaculture"    

2.3.3 Convert species code to species name in english
Interpret species code


Spesies <- species[ species$"3Alpha_Code" %in% c("SAL", "CHI", "CHU", "COH", "CHE", "PIN", "SOC") , ]



convert the code to spacies name


salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="SAL"]<-"Atlantic Salmon"
salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="PIN"]<-"Humpback Salmon"
salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="CHU"]<-"Keta Salmon"
salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="CHE"]<-"Cherry Salmon"
salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="SOC"]<-"Red Salmon"
salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="CHI"]<-"King Salmon"
salmon$SPECIES[salmon$SPECIES=="COH"]<-"Silver Salmon"

unique(salmon$SPECIES)


[1] "Atlantic Salmon" "Cherry Salmon"   "Red Salmon"     
[4] "King Salmon"     "Silver Salmon"   "Keta Salmon"    
[7] "Humpback Salmon"

2.3.4 Character to factor


salmon$COUNTRY <- as.factor(salmon$COUNTRY)
salmon$SOURCE <- as.factor(salmon$SOURCE)
salmon$SPECIES <- as.factor(salmon$SPECIES)
salmon$YEAR <- as.factor(salmon$YEAR)



Im just need year at 2018 so, i subset it


salmon <- salmon[ salmon$YEAR == 2018, ]
salmon <- salmon[ , c("COUNTRY", "SOURCE", "SPECIES", "QUANTITY")]



Now the data is ready to explore
3 Data Exploratory and Explanatory
3.1 Most popular species


salmon_species <- as.data.frame(sort(prop.table(table(droplevels(salmon[ , "SPECIES" ]))), 
                                     decreasing = T))
names(salmon_species)[1] <- paste("Salmon Species")
head(salmon_species, 3)


   Salmon Species      Freq
1 Atlantic Salmon 0.4393939
2 Humpback Salmon 0.1212121
3   Silver Salmon 0.1212121

Ok this is the top 3 of the most popular salmon
I try to make a pie chart


graphics::pie(xtabs(~ SPECIES, salmon))




3.2 Where they came from
First, Atlantic Salmon


Atlantic_Salmon_Source <- as.data.frame(sort(prop.table(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SPECIES == "Atlantic Salmon","SOURCE"]))),decreasing = T))
names(Atlantic_Salmon_Source)[1] <- paste("Atlantic Salmon")
Atlantic_Salmon_Source


         Atlantic Salmon      Freq
1        Capture Fishery 0.6206897
2     Marine Aquaculture 0.2758621
3 Freshwater Aquaculture 0.1034483

So capture fisheries practice is still being carried out, even though this species is already under threat
Second, Humpback Salmon


Humpback_Salmon_Source <- as.data.frame(sort(prop.table(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SPECIES == "Humpback Salmon","SOURCE"]))),decreasing = T))
names(Humpback_Salmon_Source)[1] <- paste("Humpback Salmon")
Humpback_Salmon_Source


     Humpback Salmon  Freq
1    Capture Fishery 0.875
2 Marine Aquaculture 0.125

Third, Silver Salmon


Silver_Salmon_Source <- as.data.frame(sort(prop.table(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SPECIES == "Silver Salmon","SOURCE"]))),decreasing = T))
names(Silver_Salmon_Source)[1] <- paste("Silver  Salmon")
Silver_Salmon_Source


          Silver  Salmon  Freq
1        Capture Fishery 0.625
2     Marine Aquaculture 0.250
3 Freshwater Aquaculture 0.125

From three species above, the conclusion is capture fisheries still dominate the output of production.
3.3 Aquaculture
I am curious, what species are cultivated? Start from Freshwater Aquaculture


Freshwater_Aquaculture <- as.data.frame(sort(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SOURCE == "Freshwater Aquaculture",
                                                                     "SPECIES"]))),decreasing = T)
names(Freshwater_Aquaculture)[1] <- paste("Freshwater Aquaculture")
Freshwater_Aquaculture


  Freshwater Aquaculture Freq
1            Keta Salmon    1
2          Silver Salmon    1
3        Atlantic Salmon    3

Ok now from Marine Aquaculture


Marine_Aquaculture <- as.data.frame(sort(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SOURCE == "Marine Aquaculture",
                                                                 "SPECIES"]))),decreasing = T)
names(Marine_Aquaculture)[1] <- paste("Marine Aquaculture")
Marine_Aquaculture


  Marine Aquaculture Freq
1    Humpback Salmon    1
2      Silver Salmon    2
3    Atlantic Salmon    8

So based on the data above, not only top three species, but keta salmon is also cultivated
3.4 Country and cultivation
which countries did cultivation? From Freshwater Aquaculture First


Country_Freshwater_Aquaculture <- as.data.frame(sort(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SOURCE == "Freshwater Aquaculture" , "COUNTRY"]))),decreasing = T)
names(Country_Freshwater_Aquaculture)[1] <- paste("Freshwater Aquaculture")
Country_Freshwater_Aquaculture


  Freshwater Aquaculture Freq
1                Denmark    1
2                  Chile    2
3     Russian Federation    2

And then Marine Aquaculture


Country_Marine_Aquaculture <- as.data.frame(sort(table(droplevels(salmon[salmon$SOURCE == "Marine Aquaculture" , "COUNTRY"]))),decreasing = T)
names(Country_Marine_Aquaculture)[1] <- paste("Marine Aquaculture")
Country_Marine_Aquaculture


        Marine Aquaculture Freq
1                   France    1
2                    Japan    1
3                   Norway    1
4           United Kingdom    1
5 United States of America    1
6                   Canada    2
7                    Chile    2
8       Russian Federation    2

Only Chile and Russia did both cultivation, however how about the production results?
Before that I need to aggregate


salmon_country_agg <- aggregate(QUANTITY ~ COUNTRY + SOURCE , salmon , sum)





fresh_aquaculture_country <- salmon_country_agg[ salmon_country_agg$SOURCE == "Freshwater Aquaculture", ]
fresh_aquaculture_country


              COUNTRY                 SOURCE QUANTITY
13              Chile Freshwater Aquaculture   683.38
14            Denmark Freshwater Aquaculture  1030.00
15 Russian Federation Freshwater Aquaculture     0.00

I was surprised, it turned out that Russia did not produce Freshwater Aquaculture in 2018


marine_aquaculture_country <- salmon_country_agg[ salmon_country_agg$SOURCE == "Marine Aquaculture", ]
marine_aquaculture_country_sorted <- marine_aquaculture_country[order(-marine_aquaculture_country$QUANTITY, marine_aquaculture_country$COUNTRY),]
marine_aquaculture_country_sorted


                    COUNTRY             SOURCE  QUANTITY
20                   Norway Marine Aquaculture 1282003.2
17                    Chile Marine Aquaculture  808975.8
22           United Kingdom Marine Aquaculture  166000.0
16                   Canada Marine Aquaculture  123184.0
21       Russian Federation Marine Aquaculture   20632.0
19                    Japan Marine Aquaculture   18000.0
23 United States of America Marine Aquaculture   16107.0
18                   France Marine Aquaculture     300.0



graphics::barplot(xtabs(QUANTITY ~ COUNTRY,marine_aquaculture_country_sorted))




as well known Norway definitely the highest of Salmon production in Marine Aquaculture
4. Conclusion
So it is actually not easy to cultivate salmon, but the positive thing is that many technologies have been developed to cultivate salmon. Cultivation is also not always positive, the cons is that production costs are too expensive. My assumptions, an easy solution to keep the population of salmon still sustainable is to limit the catch by weight or by fishing season, and improve the technologies for Aquaculture to make the cost is cheaper. I think that is enough, thanks for reading my Rmd.
5. Reference
http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-production/en  Cover photo by Marcos Paulo Prado on Unsplash  This article also available on Medium and Rpubs

title: Wicked Tuna
description: Atlantic Bluefin Tuna now is endangered because overexploited, I want to find out current condition.
contents:
1. Intro
1.1 Greetings
Helo, Welcome to My Rmd In this Rmd I would explore about Tuna
1.2 Brief
I want to visualize some graphs to inform a Tuna condition
1.3 Problem Background
Atlantic Bluefin Tuna now is endangered because overexploited, I want to find out current condition.  1. Which species are the most exploited?  2. Which countries exploit the most?  3. What is the solution to the current condition?



Figure 1: Red List Tuna.



1.4 Library


library(tidyverse)
library(readr)
library(ggthemes)
library(plotly)



1.5 Dataset
Dataset is from FAO Fisheries Division  “FAO Aquaculture, Capture and Global production databases with data from 1950 to 2018”


country <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_COUNTRY_GROUPS.csv")
production <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_PRODUCTION_SOURCE.csv")
species <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_SPECIES_GROUPS.csv")
symbol <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_SYMBOL.csv")
unit <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_UNIT.csv")
waterarea <- read_csv("input_fish/CL_FI_WATERAREA_GROUPS.csv")
TS <- read_csv("input_fish/TS_FI_PRODUCTION.csv")



2. Data Wrangling
2.1 Filter the Species
I looking for the names of colomn


names(species) #Check colomn names


 [1] "3Alpha_Code"     "Taxonomic_Code"  "Identifier"     
 [4] "Name_En"         "Name_Fr"         "Name_Es"        
 [7] "Name_Ar"         "Name_Cn"         "Name_Ru"        
[10] "Scientific_Name" "Author"          "Family"         
[13] "Order"           "Major_Group"     "Yearbook_Group" 
[16] "ISSCAAP_Group"   "CPC_Class"       "CPC_Group"      

I use three colomn ‘3Alpha_Code’, Name_En and Scientific_Name to extract the code


Nama_Tuna <- species %>% 
  select('3Alpha_Code', Name_En, Scientific_Name) %>% 
  filter(Name_En %in% c("Atlantic bluefin tuna", "Southern bluefin tuna", "Pacific bluefin tuna", "Bigeye tuna", "Albacore", "Longtail tuna", "Blackfin tuna", "Yellowfin tuna")) #Filtering species



Species


Nama_Tuna


# A tibble: 8 × 3
  `3Alpha_Code` Name_En               Scientific_Name   
  <chr>         <chr>                 <chr>             
1 BFT           Atlantic bluefin tuna Thunnus thynnus   
2 PBF           Pacific bluefin tuna  Thunnus orientalis
3 LOT           Longtail tuna         Thunnus tonggol   
4 BLF           Blackfin tuna         Thunnus atlanticus
5 ALB           Albacore              Thunnus alalunga  
6 SBF           Southern bluefin tuna Thunnus maccoyii  
7 YFT           Yellowfin tuna        Thunnus albacares 
8 BET           Bigeye tuna           Thunnus obesus    

The code has been extracted, next replace the code with species names
Decode - Encode
I use Time Series dataset from 1950 to 2018


TUNA <- TS %>% 
  filter(SPECIES %in% c("BFT", 
                        "PBF", 
                        "LOT", 
                        "BLF", 
                        "ALB", 
                        "SBF", 
                        "YFT", 
                        "BET"),
         YEAR %in% 1950:2018)



Replacing
I using sapply function for this step


TUNA$SPECIES <- sapply(as.character(TUNA$SPECIES), switch, 
                       "BFT" = "Atlantic Bluefin Tuna",
                       "PBF" = "Pacific Bluefin Tuna", 
                       "LOT" = "Longtail Tuna", 
                       "BLF" = "Blackfin Tuna", 
                       "ALB" = "Albacore",
                       "SBF" = "Southern Bluefin Tuna", 
                       "YFT" = "Yellowfin Tuna",
                       "BET" = "Bigeye Tuna")



2.2 The Country
Now, country who harvesting Tuna. There are 21 top country I got from FAO and then I filtering from country dataset


topFAO <- country %>% 
  filter(Name_En %in% c("Thailand", "Spain", "Ecuador", "Taiwan Province of China", "China", "Indonesia", "Korea, Republic of", "Viet Nam", "Philippines", "Netherlands", "Mauritius", "Japan", "United States of America", "Italy", "France", "Germany", "United Kingdom", "Australia", "Canada", "Portugal", "Saudi Arabia")) %>% 
  select(UN_Code, Name_En)



OK, I got the code of country
Filter Code of Country


TUNA <- TUNA %>% 
  filter(COUNTRY %in% c("036", "124", "156", "158", "218", "250", "276", "360", "380", "392", "410", "480", "528", "608", "620", "682", "704", "724", "764", "826", "840"))



After that I do the same things like before on Species
Decode - Encode


TUNA$COUNTRY <- sapply(as.character(TUNA$COUNTRY), switch, 
                            "036" = "Australia",
                            "124" = "Canada", 
                            "156" = "China", 
                            "158" = "Taiwan Province of China", 
                            "218" = "Ecuador",
                            "250" = "France", 
                            "276" = "Germany",
                            "360" = "Indonesia",
                            "380" = "Italy",
                            "392" = "Japan", 
                            "410" = "Korea, Republic of", 
                            "480" = "Mauritius", 
                            "528" = "Netherlands",
                            "608" = "Philippines", 
                            "620" = "Portugal",
                            "682" = "Saudi Arabia",
                            "704" = "Viet Nam",
                            "724" = "Spain", 
                            "764" = "Thailand", 
                            "826" = "United Kingdom", 
                            "840" = "United States of America")



2.3 Fishing Ground
Now, where the fish is capturing. The Fishing ground


fishing_ground <- waterarea %>% 
  filter(Code %in% c("77", "87", "21", "67", "61", "71", "27", "31", "51", "57", "81", "34", "37", "47", "41")) %>% 
  select(Code, Name_en)





TUNA$AREA <- sapply(as.character(TUNA$AREA), switch,
                    "77" = "Pacific, Eastern Central",
                    "87" = "Pacific, Southeast",
                    "21" = "Atlantic, Northwest",
                    "67" = "Pacific, Northeast",
                    "61" = "Pacific, Northwest",
                    "71" = "Pacific, Western Central",
                    "27" = "Atlantic, Northeast",
                    "31" = "Atlantic, Western Central",
                    "51" = "Indian Ocean, Western", 
                    "57" = "Indian Ocean, Eastern",
                    "81" = "Pacific, Southwest",
                    "34" = "Atlantic, Eastern Central",
                    "37" = "Mediterranean and Black Sea",
                    "47" = "Atlantic, Southeast",
                    "41" = "Atlantic, Southwest")



2.4 Source
Another to hervesting the Tuna is from Marine Aquaculture


TUNA$SOURCE <- sapply(as.character(TUNA$SOURCE), switch,
                      "3" = "Marine Aquaculture",
                      "4" = "Capture Fisheries")



2.5 Sub-Genus
In this step I did a little future enginering, create a new colomn ._.





Thunnus <- Thunnus %>% 
  mutate(FIN = SPECIES)



Next, species grouping by their sub-genus


Thunnus$FIN <- sapply(as.character(Thunnus$FIN), switch, 
                      "Atlantic Bluefin Tuna" = "Bluefin",
                      "Pacific Bluefin Tuna" = "Bluefin", 
                      "Longtail Tuna" = "Yellowfin", 
                      "Blackfin Tuna" ="Yellowfin", 
                      "Albacore" = "Bluefin",
                      "Southern Bluefin Tuna" = "Bluefin", 
                      "Yellowfin Tuna" = "Yellowfin",
                      "Bigeye Tuna" = "Bluefin")






3 EDA | Exploratory Data Analysis
3.1 Total Catch by Fishing Ground



Pacific, Southeast is the closest ocean to Indonesia, it could be that Indonesian fishermen catch tuna at this fishing ground. The species most frequently capture is Yellowfin Tuna, which is NT IUCN status or near threatened. However, if they are almost threatened, then are they the most worthy of exploitation?
3.2 Total Yearly Catch by Sub-Genus
